Introduction to seededlda

The package for semi-supervised topic modeling

Source: vignettes/pkgdown/basic.Rmd
basic.Rmd

seededlda is crated mianly for semi-supervided topic modeling but it can perform unsupervided topic modeling too. I explain the basic functions of the package taking unsupervided topic modeling as an example in this page and discuss semi-supervised topic modeling in a separate page.

Preperation

We use download the corpus of Sputnik articles about Ukraine in the articles. In the preprocessing, we remove grammatical words stopwords("en"), email addresses "*@* and words that occur in more than 10% of documents max_docfreq = 0.1 from the document-feature matrix (DFM).

library(seededlda)
library(quanteda)

corp <- readRDS("data_corpus_sputnik2022.rds")
toks <- tokens(corp, remove_punct = TRUE, remove_symbols = TRUE, 
               remove_numbers = TRUE, remove_url = TRUE)
dfmt <- dfm(toks) |> 
    dfm_remove(stopwords("en")) |>
    dfm_remove("*@*") |>
    dfm_trim(max_docfreq = 0.1, docfreq_type = "prop")
print(dfmt)
#> Document-feature matrix of: 8,063 documents, 58,541 features (99.77% sparse) and 4 docvars.
#>              features
#> docs          reiterated commitment diplomacy worsened reporters urge best
#>   s1092644731          1          1         8        1         2    1    1
#>   s1092643478          0          0         0        0         0    0    0
#>   s1092643372          0          0         0        0         0    0    0
#>   s1092643164          0          0         0        0         0    0    0
#>   s1092641413          0          0         6        0         0    0    0
#>   s1092640142          0          0         0        0         0    0    0
#>              features
#> docs          forward continuing buildup
#>   s1092644731       1          2       2
#>   s1092643478       0          0       0
#>   s1092643372       1          0       0
#>   s1092643164       0          0       0
#>   s1092641413       0          1       0
#>   s1092640142       0          0       0
#> [ reached max_ndoc ... 8,057 more documents, reached max_nfeat ... 58,531 more features ]

Standard LDA

You can analyze the DFM only by specifying the number of topics k = 10 to identify. When verbose = TRUE, it shows the progress of the inference through iterations. It takes long to fit LDA on a large corpus, but distributed algorithm will speed up the function dramatically.

lda <- textmodel_lda(dfmt, k = 10, verbose = TRUE)
#> Fitting LDA with 10 topics
#>  ...initializing
#>  ...Gibbs sampling in 2000 iterations
#>  ......iteration 100 elapsed time: 30.79 seconds (delta: -0.01%)
#>  ......iteration 200 elapsed time: 58.19 seconds (delta: 0.03%)
#>  ......iteration 300 elapsed time: 89.45 seconds (delta: 0.04%)
#>  ......iteration 400 elapsed time: 119.05 seconds (delta: 0.03%)
#>  ......iteration 500 elapsed time: 147.47 seconds (delta: -0.03%)
#>  ......iteration 600 elapsed time: 176.00 seconds (delta: 0.04%)
#>  ......iteration 700 elapsed time: 205.73 seconds (delta: -0.06%)
#>  ......iteration 800 elapsed time: 235.70 seconds (delta: 0.03%)
#>  ......iteration 900 elapsed time: 262.89 seconds (delta: 0.05%)
#>  ......iteration 1000 elapsed time: 303.78 seconds (delta: -0.05%)
#>  ......iteration 1100 elapsed time: 357.01 seconds (delta: -0.07%)
#>  ......iteration 1200 elapsed time: 400.85 seconds (delta: 0.01%)
#>  ......iteration 1300 elapsed time: 430.35 seconds (delta: -0.01%)
#>  ......iteration 1400 elapsed time: 459.54 seconds (delta: -0.02%)
#>  ......iteration 1500 elapsed time: 491.49 seconds (delta: -0.02%)
#>  ......iteration 1600 elapsed time: 542.42 seconds (delta: -0.00%)
#>  ......iteration 1700 elapsed time: 593.80 seconds (delta: -0.05%)
#>  ......iteration 1800 elapsed time: 644.49 seconds (delta: 0.06%)
#>  ......iteration 1900 elapsed time: 693.85 seconds (delta: 0.04%)
#>  ......iteration 2000 elapsed time: 745.06 seconds (delta: -0.01%)
#>  ...computing theta and phi
#>  ...complete

Topic terms

Once model is fit, you can can interpret the topics by reading the most salient words in the topics. terms() shows words that are most frequent in each topic at the top of the matrix.

knitr::kable(terms(lda))
topic1 topic2 topic3 topic4 topic5 topic6 topic7 topic8 topic9 topic10
azov per johnson hunter alliance air german joins india dpr
photo fuel british twitter lavrov systems stream joined taiwan grain
mediabank crude trump biological proposals missile nord journalist indian lpr
killed imports truss research say missiles french hour chinese finland
civilians production congress intelligence diplomatic equipment pipeline talk cooperation turkey
battalion cap boris photo borders training macron author beijing sweden
human companies election activities interests aircraft france analyst africa plant
police exports democrats company zelensky army commission professor south zaporozhye
mariupol costs bill investigation course vehicles restrictions spoke iran shelling
refugees cost republicans post soviet artillery brussels mark trade turkish

Document topics

You can also predict the topics of documents using topics(). I recommend extracting the document variables from the DFM in the fitted object lda$data and saving the topics in the data.frame.

dat <- docvars(lda$data)
dat$topic <- topics(lda)
knitr::kable(head(dat[,c("date", "topic", "head")], 10))
date topic head
2022-01-31 topic5 Biden: US Desires Diplomacy But ‘Ready No Matter What Happens’ If Ukraine Tensions Worsen
2022-01-31 topic7 EU Trade Commissioner Says Nord Stream 2 ‘on Pause’ Pending Review of Compliance With European Laws
2022-01-31 topic5 Russian Assets in UK May Be Frozen in Accordance With New Sanctions Bill, Foreign Secretary Says
2022-01-31 topic4 Hunter Biden Was Reportedly Subpoenaed Over Dealings With China a Year Before Presidential Election
2022-01-31 topic5 US Urges UN Security Council to Act on Ukraine Crisis as Russia Denies Invasion Claims
2022-01-31 topic5 UN Security Council Holds Meeting on Ukrainian Crisis
2022-01-31 topic5 The Depth of US Cold War Thinking and Murder of JFK
2022-01-31 topic5 UK PM Johnson Says He Will Tell Putin to ‘Step Back From the Brink’ in Ukraine
2022-01-31 topic5 Kremlin on UK Sanctions Threat: Attack on Russian Businesses Means There Will Be Retaliation
2022-01-31 topic5 Ukraine Crisis Escalation Forces Boris Johnson to Cancel Visit to Japan, Reports Say

References

  • Watanabe, K., & Baturo, A. (2023). Seeded Sequential LDA: A Semi-Supervised Algorithm for Topic-Specific Analysis of Sentences. Social Science Computer Review. https://doi.org/10.1177/08944393231178605
